Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. BACKSTAGE, CAPITAL BEAT STUDIO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam gets up from the make-up chair and walks along with MARK GOTTFRIED, host of Capital Beat.

Dialogues.Line: It's not gonna be Wengland.
What happened?
He's stuck in Denver.
I wanted Wengland.
Yeah.
Did you get Stackhouse?
Couldn't get Stackhouse, couldn't get Santana, couldn't get Munroe...
Who'd you get?
A woman - named Ainsley Hayes...
Aimsley?
Ainsley, with an 'n'.
I don't know her.
Me neither, but I've got a producer, he brought her in...
Mark, tell me she's not one of these...
She is.
I thought that was over?
No, no, it's not. She's got blonde hair, long legs and she's a Republican, so she's...
She's in show business.
Yeah.
A young, blonde, leggy Republican.
Yeah.
I thought it turned out they didn't know anything?
They don't. An aide with a headset comes up, holding a clipboard.
Sam.
Yeah. Mark pats him on the shoulder and moves away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. CAPITAL BEAT STUDIO - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: AINSLEY HAYES is seated. She stands as Mark approaches.

Dialogues.Line: Ainsley?
[brightly] Yes.
Mark Gottfried.
Ainsley Hayes.
[looking at his watch] So, we'll be starting here in about a minute. I understand you've never done T.V. before?
No, no, not as such, no.
Not as such? What does that mean?
It means no, I haven't done T.V. before.
Okay. Well, can I give you a little friendly advice?
Yes, I would appreciate it.
Don't overreach.
Don't overreach?
Don't try to do too much. Don't try to know more than you do. My show is not the place for you to become a star.
Okay.
You'll be opposite Sam Seaborn. He's done the show a couple dozen times; the White House wouldn't keep sending him if he didn't keep wiping the floor with whoever's in your chair.
I've seen him.
[pointing at her] Don't be scared.
[smiling] I'll try. Mark comes around the desk to sit down, and Ainsley sits too.
I'll step in, and I'll take some of the punches for you if it gets out of hand, but if you don't get too far from the talking points I'm sure that somebody will give you. Okay?
[speaking over him] Yeah.
You'll be fine.
Thirty seconds.
Are we starting with the education package?
Yeah. Sam comes in and points to somebody off-screen.
George! You owe me twenty bucks on the Skins.
In the Green Room, man. Sam shakes hands with Ainsley.
I'm Sam Seaborn.
Ainsley Hayes.
Twenty seconds.
You bet with George on the Skins?
[moving across to take his seat] Over under.
How's Josh?
He's good.
Ten seconds.
Here we go. [to Ainsley] Remember what I said.
Yeah.
In five, four, three... Lights dim, and the director continues the count silently on his fingers. A T.V. screen lights up with the Capital Beat logo.

Capital Beat with Mark Gottfried. Tonight from the right, Republican political analyst Ainsley Hayes, and from the left, White House Senior Advisor Sam Seaborn. With Chris Eisen at the Pentagon, and Marjorie Clarke in New York. [Lights go on.]

Good evening. Before we get to Chris and Marjorie tonight on the Capital Beat, the House is expected to vote next week on President Bartlet's one point five billion dollar education package. Sam Seaborn: Why is this bill better than its Republican counterpart that the President vetoed last year? Ainsley takes up a pen ready to take notes.

Because it buys things the teachers need. Like textbooks. In a fairly comprehensive study that was done, an alarmingly high number of teachers - forty percent of teachers in Kirkwood, Oregon, for instance, and Kirkwood, Oregon being a fair model for public school districts across the country - forty percent of the teachers in Kirkwood, Oregon report not having sufficient textbooks for their students. [Ainsley is taking notes.] The package offered by the Republican controlled Congress offered a grand total of zero dollars for new textbooks.
Ainsley Hayes? Is that true?
[still writing] No, it's not.
Is Sam Seaborn lying?
Lying's an awfully strong word...
Do you...?
[finally looking up] Yes, he's lying.
I don't...
[talking over him] And we should tell the truth about education.
Well, if you're gonna call...

The bill contained plenty of money for new textbooks. Also computer literacy, school safety, physical plants. The difference is we wanted to give the money directly to communities, and let them decide how best to spend it, on the off-chance that the needs of Lincoln High in Dayton are different from the needs of Crenshaw High in South Central L.A.
Sam, why did the President veto the bill?
There are...

[talking over him] Because it guaranteed by law that ninety-five percent of the money go directly into the classroom and bypassed the pork-barrel buffet, which is troubling to this President because he doesn't work for the students...
[quietly] Well that's just...
...and he doesn't work for the parents of the students. He works for the teacher's union.
The difference with the old... He and Mark exchange wry smiles as Ainsley interrupts again.

The bill contains plenty of money for textbooks, Mark, and anyone who says otherwise is flat-out lying. And we should tell the truth about textbooks. Textbooks are important, if for no other reason than they'd accurately place the town of Kirkwood in California and not in Oregon.
[to the camera] And we're in business. We'll be back with more Capital Beat after this.
Out. The T.V. screen goes black and displays the words PLACE COMMERCIAL HERE.
I'm sorry, did I overreach? Mark chuckles and gets up, leaning over Sam.
Hey, Sam.
Yeah.
This one might know something.
[quietly] Yeah. [to himself] Please, oh, please, let them not be watching.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: [in the doorway] Toby. Come quick! Sam's getting his ass kicked by a girl! He scurries away and Toby leaps to his feet.
Ginger, get the popcorn! He dashes after Josh.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: There'll be a photo op in the Mural Room...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: ...in a half hour with President Bartlet and President Nimbala of the Republic of Equatorial Kuhndu who's representing the African nations.
[standing] Um, C.J., is it the goal of the summit to get the drug companies to lower their prices, or is the goal to get the African countries to honour U.S. patents?

The goal of the summit is to get a step closer to solving twenty-six million African AIDS victims. [Toby watches in the background.] We're counting on the drug companies, we're counting on the African nations, we're counting on the global health community and they're counting on the White House to help broker a solution.
Is the White House prepared to declare war on the drug companies?
Well, it sounds like you already have, so if we need a button man, we'll call you. Thank you, everybody, half hour in the Mural Room. Carol approaches from the side.
[to Carol] Tell them they need to be in three groups.
Yeah. They both exit the Press Room, and Toby joins C.J. as they walk in the
You know what you might have mentioned?
It was a 14 minute briefing, I'm really gonna get reviews?
You might have mentioned that the same drug that costs ten dollars and eighty cents in Norway, where nobody needs it, costs ninety dollars in Burundi, where everybody needs it.
There is nothing keeping these people here but good will, Toby! They can charge what they want for their products.
It sounds to me like we intend to be soft on the drug companies.
Toby, I don't think anybody expects this White House to be anything but tough on American companies showing a profit.
Damn right. Toby comes to a stop in the doorway of C.J.'S OFFICE. Sam comes up behind Toby.
Where was the 1992 World Copyright Conference?
Geneva.
Thank you. [turns to go]
[calling after him] Sam! I've really gotta admire the way you came into work this morning, head held high.
And I appreciate your being the one person who's managed to abstain from heckling me.
No problem. [as he turns to go] There's a whole bunch of women over there. Why don't you ask them whether Geneva's in Switzerland or Oregon?
[angry] Okay!
[to Sam] Go to my office.
Me and you, twenty questions, short answer, general knowledge test, right now!
Go to my office.
I'll spot you two questions.
How much money?
Go to my office.
I'm going to his office. C.J. starts making chicken noises. Sam pauses in the doorway and turns to look at Toby.
She's making the chicken sound now.
Go to my office. Sam looks back at C.J. and then departs.
[to C.J.] That drug they've gotta buy from us for four dollars a unit, they can get generic from Pakistan for forty cents.
[walking past him] That's not the only bargain in Pakistan, Toby. My girlfriends and I go for the spring fashions.
It shows. C.J. turns to give him a look and he goes off down a side corridor. A young reporter, Bill, comes up behind her.
[pointing in the direction Toby went] He just made a little dig about my clothes, and that's what's gonna be with me the rest of the day.
C.J., I wanted to introduce myself, I'm Bill Kelley from the Cleveland Courier?
[shaking his hand] Hi.
They're breaking me in to cover for Tom Johnson, I've been sitting in the back.
Welcome.
Can I ask you something?
That's what I'm here for.
Do you know anything about Bonamo Energy selling drilling equipment to Iraq?
I'm not gonna wave you off the story, but I can't tell you anything about it.
[stopping her] If they were selling the Iraqis drilling equipment, that would be in violation of sanctions, wouldn't it?
Grand jury investigations are secret, Bill. I can't tell you any more about it.
I understand. Nice meeting you.
Nice meeting you. She walks on and then freezes in sudden realization. She turns.
Bill!
Yeah?
Nothing. Just... nothing.
Okay. C.J. looks concerned for a minute, then walks off.
Then you've got guys like Mbeki who turn around and say...

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PORTICO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Leo are walking along.

Dialogues.Line: ...that AIDS isn't linked to HIV, it's linked to poverty.
It is linked to poverty.
Would you like me to show you the list of dead millionaires?
He was saying that prostitutes, migrant laborers, the ill-educated, and victims of sexual abuse are more likely...
Leo, AIDS is caused by HIV. You just named a group of people that have a higher mortality rate across the board. Morning, Charlie.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Where are we?
We're all set, sir, whenever you're ready.
Thank you. Bartlet and Leo walk inside THE OVAL OFFICE.
It was the Health Minister trying to clear up his comments.
They have a Health Minister who doesn't think AIDS is connected to HIV!
He was clearing up the comments.
[stopping at his desk] Hey, did you see Sam get purEed last night on Capital Beat? [puts on his glasses]
[amused] I didn't see it, but I have heard tell.
He got diced and sliced by a woman named Ainsley Hayes.
She's been writing some columns.
I know, I had Charlie pull 'em for me. Where's she been?
She was clerking for Dreifort.
We should hire her.
That'd be funny!
No, I mean it.
Mean what?
We should hire her.
What, you mean as a joke on Sam?
No, not as a joke, I mean we should hire her as a reality. We should hire her.
She's a Republican.
So are half the people in this country.
Well, that half lost, so...
She's smart, she's not just carping. She feels a sense of something.
Of what?
[entering the room] Mr. President.
Yeah. [to Leo] Of duty. Of civic duty.
[as they leave the room] How many pieces by her did you read?
Three.
And you're certain of her sense of civic duty?
I can sense civic duty a mile away.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Morning. The press are gathered in THE MURAL ROOM. Bartlet enters.
Good morning.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Morning everybody.
Good morning, Mr. President. Bartlet approaches PRESIDENT NIMBALA.
Good morning, Mr. President.
Good morning, sir. They shake hands.
[to the press] You can tell your caption editors that Bartlet's the third guy from the right.
Thank you, sir. [to the press] Presidents Bartlet and Nimbala will take just a few questions.
President Bartlet.
Katie.
This is a summit among leaders of American pharmaceutical companies and the
ravaged African nations that President Nimbala is representing here. The translator whispers to Nimbala.
Is there a political upside to only having President Nimbala at this photo op and not the pharmaceutical companies?
[sarcastic] Yes, Katie, I'm trying to shore up the sub-Saharan vote.
Um, Mr. President, are you considering asking Congress to forgive existing debts?
It's an international health crisis; there's nothing I'm not considering.
[pointing] Arthur?
President Nimbala, what's the best you can hope to come away with from this summit? The translator whispers.
What's a home run?
A miracle.

There are people who make miracles in the world. One of them lives right here in the U.S. He realized that vital elements could be harvested from the stalk of the wheat. In his hands, India, which at the time had been ravaged by drought and overpopulation - in his hands, the wheat crop increased from 11 million tons to 60 million tons annually.
[nodding] That's right. His name is Norman Borlaug, by the way, and he won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970.
Thank you, Mr. President, President Nimbala. Thank you everyone. The press start to disperse.
[to Nimbala] I think you're absolutely right about the kind of miracle we need. I think we're gonna make a lot of progress in the next few days.
I hope so, Mr. President. My country's dying. Bartlet looks down for a moment, then nods in acknowlegement and turns to leave. Leo catches up with him as he walks back to THE OVAL OFFICE.
It was called dwarf wheat, which produces heavy yields without its stalk falling over from the weight of the rain.
Was it a hybrid?
What am I, Farmer Bob? It was wheat, and there was more than there used to be.
Okay!
And hire that girl.
What girl?
Ainsley Hayes.
No.
Why?
'Cause this is one of those things you're excited about after breakfast that you forget you told me to do by lunch.
[waggling a finger at him] Not one of those.
It's one of those.
Leo, as hard as you might try, the Republican Party isn't going anywhere.
You don't know that for sure, sir, they could all end up moving to Vancouver.
I don't think so.
Me neither, but being in power means everybody else can take a seat for four years. Charlie comes in and hands Bartlet a mug as he sits at his desk.
Charlie, I want to hire a woman whose voice I think would fit in nicely around here, she's a conservative Republican. Do you think I should do it?
Absolutely, Mr. President. 'Cause I'm told that theirs is the party of inclusion. Bartlet gives him a look as he moves away.
[gesturing over his shoulder at him] See? Charlie just made a joke to you in the Oval Office. That's how bad an idea it is.
Leo.
Seriously, Mr. President, if you want to do this, it's not an uninteresting notion, let's just do it in a more high-profile place. Put a Republican in the cabinet.
We might do that, Leo. A hundred million Republicans; we might hire as many as two of them. But for now, hire this girl.
To do what?
[shrugging] I don't know. She's a lawyer. Put her in the counsel's office.
You really want me to do this?
Yes.
What if she doesn't want to work here?
Appeal to her sense of duty. And smooth it over with the staff. Really, I don't want to hear from them.
She can always have my job, you know.
Yes, she can.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you. Leo leaves.
Charlie.
Yes, sir.
When they close the book on me and you, it will say that at this moment you were not there for me, and for that, obviously, there'll be some kind of punishment.
Well, you could sing Puccini for me again, Mr. President. We'll call it even.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. CITYSCAPE - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: And anyone who says otherwise is flat-out lying.
Here it comes.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AINSLEY'S FRONT ROOM
Scenes.Description: Ainsley's friends BRUCE and HARRIET are watching her on the T.V. Ainsley is in the back fiddling with her telephone.

Dialogues.Line: Listen, does anybody here know how to...?
Shh!
Textbooks are important, if for no other reason than they'd accurately place the town of Kirkwood in California and not in Oregon.
[stops the video, grinning] Oh! I could watch that a hundred times.
Does anybody know how to work caller-ID?
Oh, how can you not know how to use a telephone?
I've been paying attention to other things.
Well, pay attention to that because Bruce's friend is gonna call you.
The agent?
Yep.
I don't need an agent, I need a caller-ID tutorial.
You need an agent, Ainsley, you're gonna be a star.
Used to be, you had to sing and dance.
You're gonna get a lot of work ripping these people to shreds, and lookin' good doing it.
That's an actual job now? The phone begins to ring.
That's him.
[consulting leaflet] Let's see, I push... this button... And the number appears.
Ainsley?
Is that the agent?
It's the White House.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Donna emerges from the office carrying a file and walks past Sam in the corridor.
Hey, Sam.
[stops and turns] Excuse me?
What?
Did you say something to me?
I, I said 'hey, Sam'...?
Really.
Yeah.
'Cause it sounded like maybe you might have made a wisecrack about Oregon... California.
Sorry, out of luck. [turns to walk off and passes C.J.] Hey, C.J..
[seeming harrassed] Hi, Donna. [marches past Sam, looking distracted]
[following] This is late for you.
I got lost.
Where?
On the way to work.
When?
Now, this morning.
You got lost on your way to work? C.J. sighs. They pass Carol on the way into C.J.'s office.
Good morning, Carol.
Morning, Carol.
Good morning, Sam. [frowning at C.J.] It's eight fifteen.
We'll do messages in a minute.
You got lost on your way to work.
[warningly] Don't make fun of me.
I wouldn't worry about that.
[rubbing her face] I didn't sleep much last night.
How much did you sleep?
None, not at all.
You slept none, not at all.
Sam!
I am, today, particularly excited about you being the spokesperson for the President.

[calling after him as he turns to go] Let me ask you something. I was talking, yesterday, to a reporter who's new in the room, and he asked me a question, and in my answer... [long pause] Let me ask you something. She is silent for another long moment.
C.J.?
Yeah.
You know you haven't asked me anything yet, right?
Yeah. [collecting herself after a moment] Yeah. Listen, never mind.
C.J.?
Seriously, forget about it.
What was your question?
[arriving in the doorway] The two of you, come take a walk with me.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: What's going on?
[turning to face them] I wanted to tell you this out where there were people so you wouldn't scream about it.
Scream about what?
The woman who was on Capital Beat with Sam Sunday night.
What about her?
I'm offering her a job.
[sharply] Where?
Here.
Are you kidding?
No.
Are you kidding?
[more firmly] No.
[getting louder] Are you kidding?
No.
[shrieking] Well, what the hell made you think I wouldn't scream where there are people?! Everyone turns to stare.
I took a shot. SAM and C.J. [shrieking in unison] Leo!
[quietly] Come this way. He motions for them both to follow him and moves off.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT - JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA - DAY

Dialogues.Line: I don't feel that I've homed in on this.
There are a lot of people in Africa with HIV.
Right.
American companies hold the patents on the medicines they need.
Yes.
Most people in most African countries can't afford to buy the drugs at these prices, so they buy them on the black market.
In violation of the U.S. patents and international treaties.
Yes.
How prohibitively priced are the drugs?
They cost about a hundred and fifty bucks a week.
Well, that's not totally off the charts.
A police officer in Kenya makes forty-three dollars a month. He straightens his jacket outside the meeting room and Donna hands him a folder.
Do good in there. Josh sighs and pushes open the door to THE ROOSEVELT ROOM.
This isn't about profit...
[pointedly] Sir!
[after a moment] This isn't about profit...
Sir, you have interrupted me again.
My apologies, Mr. President. Nimbala begins to talk, as Josh quietly rounds the table and takes a seat.
How can you tell us this isn't about profit maximisation? Why do you sell Amprex for half the price in Norway than you do in my country?
I don't think that's the issue.
[abruptly] Let's make it the issue.
Toby!
Let's make it the issue for the moment, please.
You can't compare prices worldwide, Toby.
Sir, excuse me, sir.
[exasperated] Yes?
I am the one who asked you the question. I'd appreciate it if you directed your answer to me.
President Nimbala. When you sell to small pharmacies, as we do in Norway, a different price is set.
Norway, ten dollars per unit U.S.; my country, twenty-three dollars per unit
Retail mark-up, taxes, pharmacy discounts... these things vary widely.
Not to mention the fact that we don't even know if the drugs are getting to your citizens.
You're implying corruption and incompetence.
[leaning forward] We do have reports of that, Mr. President.
You talk to me about corruption. What are your annual sales of Fluconazole alone?
A billion dollars.
I don't understand your point, sir.
I think President Nimbala's saying that there's more money in giving a white guy an erection than curing a black guy of AIDS.

Sir, my company has given away over a hundred and twenty million dollars worth of free drugs a year. Including free doses of Zyclocint, which is one of two drugs in your country curing eye infection right now.
They're not dying from eye infections, Alan.
Well, they're not dying 'cause of me either, Toby. And I'd like not to be talked to this way.
Alan, if it was 26 million Europeans dying, we'd have had a solution yesterday. Josh leans back in his chair and rubs his face.
How much would it cost for you to provide free drugs to the Sahelise Republic, Kenya, and the Republic of Equatorial Kuhndu?
[shrugging] I have no idea.
Why not? We're talking about a hundred and thirty thousand patients, two hundred milligram pills, three times a day every day. What's the X-factor?
We don't know how long they'll live.
[after a moment] We're nowhere. Let's take a break. He gets up and leaves the room, and the others start to follow.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: [entering] Leo.
Yeah.
She's here.
Good.
Should I send her in?
Yeah.
Want me to stay here?
Why?
In case something should happen.
What would that be, exactly?
[leaving] I'll bring her in.
Thank you. He gets up and walks to the door, shaking hands with Ainsley as she arrives.
Ainsley.
Mr. McGarry.
Leo's fine.
Yeah.
[closes the door] Were you offered coffee or something to drink?
Yes, the woman who works out there, who I imagine is your secretary, offered me coffee or something.
Okay.
She was also kind enough to ask for my coat.
Excellent, and...
She seems to be a very good secretary.
She'll be happy to hear that, she's standing right outside the door. He thumps his hand on the door.
Ow.
[returning to his desk] So, I have to tell you, I've never seen Sam Seaborn get beat the way you beat him on Monday.
[sitting] Yes, well, Mr. McGarry...
Leo.

Yes, sir. I've been thinking about that ever since your office called me on Tuesday, and I have something to say on my own behalf, if you'll permit me a moment to say it, and I understand if you won't, but I would really appreciate it if you did.
I... didn't really follow that, but whatever.

I think that it is wrong for a man in your position to summon someone to the White House to reprimand them for voicing opposition. I think that that is wrong, and it is inappropriate. It's inappropriate, and I'll tell you what else.
[nodding slightly] It's wrong?
Yes.
That's fine, except you weren't summoned here to be reprimanded.
Well, then, if you'll permit me, why was I summoned?
You have an interesting conversational style, do you know that?
It's a nervous condition.
I used to have a nervous condition.
How did yours manifest itself?
I drank a lot of scotch.
I get sick when I drink too much.
I get drunk when I drink too much.
Well, Mr. McGarry...
Leo.
Yes, sir. I'll ask again: for what purpose was I brought here today?
So I could offer you a job.
I'm asking because I do not think that it is fair that I be expected to play the role of the mouse to the White House's cat in the game of, well, you know the game.
Cat and mouse?

Yes. And it's not like I'm not, you know... the fact that I may not look like some of the other Republicans who have crossed your path does not mean I am any less inclined towards... [comes to a sudden stop]
Here it comes.
Did you say offer me a job?
Yes. Associate White House counsel. You'd report to the Deputy White House Counsel, who reports to the White House Counsel, who reports to me.
I'm sorry... A job in this White House?
You want a glass of scotch?
Yes, please.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam looks through the window and sees C.J. lying on her couch with a cloth over her eyes.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.?
Yeah? Sam comes in and stops in the doorway.
C.J., see a sleep doctor. Take a pill. Do something.
I rode the Lifecycle this morning for an hour and a half. If it was a real cycle, I'd be in Belgium by now.
[sitting down] C.J., what did you want to ask me the other day?
Sam, if I talked to you about it, you could be subpoenaed.
Don't worry about it.
It could cost you...
[more firmly] Don't worry about it.
[sitting up] I do worry about it! [brushes back her hair] There's no problem. I just need some sleep. What can I bring into the room about the conference?
The sessions are productive. Progress is being made. These kinds of things take time. All the parties are optimistic.
Are any of the parties optimistic?
No.
[quietly] Okay.
C.J.? C.J. looks up, and Carol makes a 'get moving' gesture.
Yeah. [leaves] Sam looks up at Carol and frowns.
Did you say something to me?
No.
'Cause I thought you might have said something. Carol gives him an odd look, and leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: I have always been a Republican. My father is a Republican. His father was State Chairman of the North Carolina Republican Party.
Yes.
When I was young, I was a Young Republican.
[sitting up] Yeah, Ainsley, even if you hadn't already told me all of this, you know, many, many times, I would know it anyway, 'cause I have this FBI file.
You have my FBI file?
Yes.
I can't believe that! You have my FBI file?
Yes.
I have an FBI file?
Ainsley...
Mr. McGarry, I loathe almost everything you believe in. [stands up]
Where are you going?
I'm not going anywhere, I'm standing up, which is how one speaks in opposition in a civilized world.
Well, you go, girl.
I find this administration smug and patronizing, and under the impression that those who disagree with them are less than they are, and with colder hearts.
I don't think that's true.
How many people on your staff assumed that I was ambitious, mean, and stupid?
[firmly] None. [after a moment] C.J. Cregg thinks you kill your pets. You don't do that, do you?
No, I don't kill my pets. I don't have any pets. I was thinking about getting a pet, but-- that doesn't matter. The point is...
Ainsley.
Yes, sir.
Don't you want to work in the White House?
Oh, only since I was two.
[shrugging] Okay.
It has to be this White House?
Ainsley...
Mr. McGarry.
The President likes smart people who disagree with him. He wants to hear from you. The President's asking you to serve. And everything else is crap. He gets up and goes to open the door for her.
Think about it overnight. Come back here at six tomorrow and give me your answer. [shouting] Margaret! Margaret jumps, standing right in the doorway as he yanks it open.
How you doin'? [gives her a wry smile] Show Ms. Hayes out, would you, please?
This way.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby pushes through a door, carrying a drink with a wrapped-up danish on top of it. Josh follows behind him, eating a banana.

Dialogues.Line: You're listening to me, but you're not understanding me.
No, I'm disagreeing with you. That doesn't mean I'm not listening to you, or understanding what you're saying. I'm doing all three at the same time.
You gotta get out of their face, Toby, they can get up any time they want. We don't have anything they need. [tosses his banana skin in a trash can as they walk past]
They need patent treaties to be enforced.
And they are gonna be enforced. The pharmaceutical companies got half the House of Representatives elected. Congress is gonna get serious about this.
The pills cost 'em four cents a unit to make.
You know that's not true. The second pill cost 'em four cents; the first pill cost 'em four hundred million dollars.

They also enjoy unprecedented tax breaks, foreign tax credits, research and experimentation exemptions, and expensing of research expenditures. To say nothing of the fact that business is pretty good, so they're gonna cover their butt. Toby pushes through the door of the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE and hands the wrapped danish to Ginger.
Tell me about Nimbala. He walks on past as Toby stops to talk to Ginger.
They didn't have cheese.
What is it?
It's boysenberry.
A boysenberry danish?
[walking away] It's new. Josh is sitting waiting for him in TOBY'S OFFICE.
Tell me about Nimbala.

He's a good President, Josh. He was a great soldier, a brilliant commander, he led his people for 28 years, he can't get ahead of the curve. He's cursed by geography. You know what, if the ground won't grow anything, you don't have an economy. Still, he stands in a room and he talks about Norman Borlaug. He came here himself, Josh, he didn't send delegates. I think it's 'cause he doesn't have any. I think he's holding his country together with both hands.
Then let's make sure we send him back with something, is my point. Ginger appears in the doorway.
Fellas?
Yeah.
They're ready. Josh gets up to leave.
[quietly] Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PRESS ROOM - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Folks, please take your seats.

Good afternoon. Guess what? The aduit figures released yesterday by the Senate Finance comfirmed earlier reports released by the Congressional Budget Office regarding the increased budget projections.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BACK OF PRESS ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: The CBO's projection actually increased the surplus amount from two trillion over the next ten years to 2.2 trillion We see C.J. on a monitor as Ainsley comes up beside Bill.
This exceeds even the most optimistic estimates published last year by the White House budget office of 300 billion and the CBO's projection last quarter of 900 billion.
Are you new too?
[leaning closer] Excuse me?
Are you new too? It's my fourth day.
Uh no, no.

Maybe you can help me, then. I'm trying to get somewhere with drilling equipment that might have been sold by Bonamo Energy to the Iraqis, in violation of sanctions. I asked C.J. about it, and she said there's a grand jury investigation, and she's not allowed to talk. If you ask he she was acting a little bit-- [shrugs] Ah, I don't know. But I hear she hasn't been able to sleep, and maybe that's because...
She told you there was a grand jury investigation?
Yeah. Margaret comes up behind them.
Miss Hayes.
Yeah.
This way. They leave and Bill watches them go.
...a large portion of the surplus to debt reduction.
Is there an updated assumption-?
C.J.! C.J.!
With regard to the progress made here at the White House summit for African AIDS relief, all parties are optimistic that an agreement will be reached. We PAN across to view C.J. on a monitor.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: EXT. WHITE HOUSE - DAY
CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: I think there's a more fundamental problem than marginal costs. We've been at this for four days and I still think we haven't talked about the fundamental misunderstanding in Africa over the basic facts of AIDS.
I don't think there's a misunderstanding.
A week ago you people stood up and said that AIDS has only a casual relationship to HIV.
I'm not sure to whom you are referring when you say, 'you people', but it was President Mbeki of South Africa who said that, and not anyone in this room.
I think Mr. Damson has brought up a hard truth that should faced.
What's that?

If tomorrow we made AIDS medication free to every patient in your country, as much as they needed for as long as they needed it, it would likely make very little difference in the spread of the epidemic.
Why?

Anti-HIV drugs are a triple cocktail. It's a complicated regimen that requires ten pills to be taken every day at precise times. Two protease inhibitors every eight hours, two combination RTI pills every twelve hours.
What's the problem? There is a brief silence. Toby sighs.
They don't own wristwatches. They can't tell time. Josh rubs his temples, looking tired. There is another brief silence.

We agree that something must be done. But we don't think we're culprits, and we don't think there is an easy or obvious solution. And we think you should be aware of the dangers involved in some of the proposals made here today. Toby sighs again.
Mr. President, may we speak with you alone, please?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Margaret and Ainsley are walking along together. Ainsley stops, spotting C.J. exercising on the Lifecycle in her office.

Dialogues.Line: Ainsley?
Could-could you give me just a moment? Margaret checks her watch.
Sure.
Thank you. Ainsley walks and enters C.J.'S OFFICE.
Excuse me. I was going to see Leo McGarry. He asked me to come back and see him again at the end of the day. I'm Ainsley Hayes.
It's good to meet you.
I'm not taking the job, C.J.
Well... [shrugging] okay.
I just wanted to... okay. Ainsley turns to go as C.J. takes a swig of water, then she turns back.
C.J., rule 6[e] of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure says you can be prosecuted for even confirming that a grand jury's been impaneled.
How'd you know?
A reporter in your press room, who hasn't read the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure.
Well, someone's gonna tell him eventually.
Who told you?
One of the witnesses who was called. What could happen?

Eighteen months, medium security. [C.J. abruptly stops pedalling.] C.J., I'm kidding. You didn't break the law. Attorneys and jurors are under a gag order. Witnesses are free to say whatever they want, and anyone is free to repeat what they've said. You know, I'm not sure that laying low and hoping nobody noticed was the best strategy here. Next time, you should really run it by someone in the Counsel's Office. Anyway, I should go see Leo.
Yeah.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Nimbala is watching the rain against the window. Josh and Toby enter the room behind him.

Dialogues.Line: President Nimbala? Nimbala walks over to the seats and sits down.
I'm gonna put a deal together, and I want you to agree to it.
What am I agreeing to?

I can get them to lower their prices - but you have to commit your military, your customs bureau, and your Ministry of Health. You have to commit them to stopping the influx of black market HIV drugs from Korea and Pakistan, and from wherever else they're coming.

35.8 percent of our adult population is infected. 60 percent of our hospital beds are occupied by people who are HIV-positive. Our Institute of Policy Analysis says in the coming decade, 50 percent of all households in our country will have at least one member infected with HIV. To think I would care about International Patent Law at a time like this is unrealistic.
Mr. President. The U.S. Department of Commerce will put your country on a watch list. That's the first step towards trade sanctions. Our Congress could end all aid to your country.

Or you can agree to what we're saying. In exchange for which we believe we can get Congress to forgive the debt, and all your past development loans, and we believe the Export-Import Bank will offer a billion dollars in loans to finance the purchase of American AIDS medication.
[disbelieving] Congress won't approve the loan!

Congress won't have to, sir. The Treasury and the State Department will review it, but if we spread the loans out over several countries in your region on a case-by-case basis, and if none of the loans exceed a hundred million dollars, we don't need Congressional approval. That law might change soon. The translator finishes relaying and Nimbala is silent for a moment.
It's a terrible thing to beg for your life. Terrible. My father- [slips back into his own language]
[to Nimbala] A proud man.
Proud? Ah. My father was a proud man. He built homes. He wouldn't like what I came here to do.
Yes he would, Mr. President. I swear to God, he would.
[after a long silence] Thank you, sir.
[to Josh] Go tell Leo. Josh gets up and leaves.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OUTSIDE LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Ainsley is studying a picture on the wall. Sam walks past carrying a folder. He pokes his head through Leo's door, sees he's not there, and then turns back and notices her.

Dialogues.Line: Hi.
[turning] Hi. Sam looks at his watch and fiddles awkwardly with his tie. He opens his folder to look at it. After a moment, Ainsley turns back to the picture.

[abruptly] You know, something you forgot to mention about the 95 percent of the money going straight into the classroom and past the pork-barrel buffet is that the school only got the money if they agreed not to distribute condoms.
Well that's a reason to veto it, because the thing our public schools need more than anything else right now are free condoms. I'd... definitely make that priority one.
[walking past into Leo's office] Hey, Sam.
Hey.
[emerging] Where's Leo?
He's not here. Josh pauses for a moment in the doorway.
You look familiar to me. [realizing] You're Ainsley Hayes!
Ainsley, uh, with an 'n'.
She works here now.
What?
Leo hired her.
What're you talking about?
Leo hired her. He told me and C.J., he was waiting to tell you and Toby.
What was he waiting for?
[exasperated] How the hell do I know, Josh?
Waiting until he hired me, which he hasn't done, 'cause I'm not taking the job.
You're not taking the job?
No. But thank you for talking to me, instead of about me.
Hey, I'm still back on he offered you the job... but you're not taking the job?
No, man, why participate in the process when you can get a job commenting on it?

You think because I don't want to work here it's because I can get a better gig on Geraldo? Gosh, let's see if there could possibly be any other reason why I wouldn't want to work in this White House? This White House that feels that government is better for children than parents are. That looks at forty years of degrading and humiliating free lunches handed out in a spectacularly failed effort to level the playing field and says, 'Let's try forty more.' This White House that says of anyone that points that out to them, that they are cold and mean and racist, and then accuses Republicans of using the politics of fear. This White House that loves the Bill of Rights, all of them - except the second one.
[looks at Josh nervously] This is the wrong place to talk about guns right now. I thought your column was idiotic.
Imagine my surprise.

[getting steadily more emotional] But for a brilliant surgical team and two centimeters of a miracle, this guy's dead right now. From bullets fired from a gun bought legally. They bought guns, they loaded them, they drove from Wheeling to Rosslyn, and until they pulled the trigger they had yet to commit a crime. I am so off-the-charts tired of the gun lobby tossing around words like 'personal freedom' and no one calling 'em on it. [Josh moves away uncomfortably.] It's not about personal freedom, and it certainly has nothing to do with public safety. It's just that some people like guns.

Yes, they do. But you know what's more insidious than that? Your gun control position doesn't have anything to do with public safety, and it's certainly not about personal freedom. It's about you don't like people who do like guns. You don't like the people. Think about that, the next time you make a joke about the South.
[coming in] Where's Leo?
[still focused on Ainsley] What?
Where's Leo?
We don't know. Charlie appears briefly in the doorway to hand a piece of paper to Toby.
Charlie, you seen Leo? Toby hands the paper to Josh and leaves. Josh reads it and then hands it to Sam, and they both go off in different directions.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh opens the door from Leo's office and goes in. Bartlet and Leo are at the desk while various other people bustle about. A military man hands Bartlet some papers.

Dialogues.Line: Yes, sir.
Television and radio?
They've got 'em.
When do I see pictures, and who's gonna tell me what I'm looking for?
Ten minutes in the Situation Room.
[looking at his watch] I want Fitzwallace and Nancy. The aide nods and leaves.
We're getting in the early CIC reports. Toby enters.
[approaching Donna] Donna, tell C.J. it's an open lid?
She knows. They're coming back. Another aide opens the door for Nimbala.
[nodding towards him] Leo.
[to the military advisors] Excuse us. [louder] Excuse me, everybody, could we have the room a moment please? The various aides and advisors clear out. Sam enters behind Nimbala.
Sam. Sam closes the door behind him. Bartlet slips on his suit jacket and looks grave as he turns to face Nimbala.
Mr. President, three hours ago there was a coup in your country. The AFRC has taken the capital.
Where are my children?
We're finding out. The information's coming very quickly now from our people in Angola and Sudan. Mr. President, I think you should sit.
No, thank you. I'll go now.
No, no, sir! My State Department is offering you asylum in the U.S.
Thank you, Mr. President, but I have to go home!
You can't go home. You can't go home!
I'm their leader.
They have the capital, they have the radio station, they have the television station.
Are there Americans on the ground?
I'm evacuating the embassy.
Have they closed the airports?
Yes.
They'll want to arrest me. They will want to put me on trial. You should trade my return for the safe departure of the Americans.

I don't need to trade you! If they won't give me the Americans, we'll go and get 'em ourselves, and they know that, and they'll let 'em go. Ainsley approaches from Leo's office and sees them talking through the door.
[firmly] I'd like to call my embassy.
Your embassy is in exile, Mr. President.
They will shoot you the moment you step off the plane. Another aide comes in and hands Bartlet a message.
Please tell me what is in that message. Bartlet puts on his glasses and reads for a moment, then looks up.
We think your brother and your two sons are already dead. We think your wife is being hidden in Kenya. You understand, don't you, why I can't offer military assistance?
Yes. Margaret comes up to where Ainsley is standing and leads her away.
Sit down, sir. Margaret closes the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. CITYSCAPE - NIGHT
CUT TO: INT. RESTAURANT - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Bruce and Harriet are sitting together.

Dialogues.Line: And you know they just wanted to hire her so they could say they did.
Yes. Look at us! We hired a Republican! Look at how bipartisan we are! We didn't even notice that she looks like a Gap dancer! Ainsley approaches and joins them.
Ainsley!
Hey.
Bruce was just telling me.
I couldn't resist.
He said they tried to hire you.
[eagerly] Tell me about the look on McGarry's face.
What?
When you said no.
I, um, couldn't see him. He had to- he was called in to-
What's wrong?
[shaking her head] Nothing. He had to- Something happened.
Uh, damn. I wanted you to say it to his face. I wanted to see...
I hate these people.
Did you meet anyone there who isn't worthless?
[quietly] Don't say that.
Did you meet anyone there who has any-?

[more firmly] I said don't say that. Say they're smug and superior, say their approach to public policy makes you want to tear your hair out. Say they like high taxes and spending your money. Say they want to take your guns and open your borders, but don't call them worthless. At least don't do it in front of me. Bruce and Harriet exchange a look.

The people that I have met have been extraordinarily qualified, their intent is good. Their commitment is true, they are righteous, and they are patriots. [after a moment, with tears in her eyes] And I'm their lawyer. She gets up and walks out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. THE WHITE HOUSE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: You ever read Paul Erlich's book?
"The Population Bomb"?
Yeah. He wrote it in 1968. Erlich said it was a fantasy that India would ever feed itself.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. TOBY'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh, Toby and Bartlet are gathered together, all in casual clothes.

Dialogues.Line: Then Norman Borlaug comes along. See the problem was wheat is top-heavy. It was falling over on itself and it took up too much space. The dwarf wheat... guys, it was an agricultural revolution that was credited with saving one billion lives. Charlie approaches and hands Bartlet a small slip of paper. He looks up at him for a moment, then puts on his glasses and takes the message. He unfolds it and looks grave.
It happened.
They executed him in the airport parking lot. There is a solemn silence, and Bartlet takes off his glasses and sighs.

Okay. I'll see you Monday. He gets up and leaves the office. A staffer stands as he walks past and then sits down. Josh leaves the office and goes in the opposite direction, while Toby just stands in silence.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
